title: 103_hr3665
content: The Act titled "Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1993" is cited as the short title. The findings and purposes of the Act are outlined in section 2. The Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1993 aims to strengthen federal motor carrier safety regulations by increasing penalties for violations to improve compliance and safety performance of drivers. Minimum penalty amounts are proposed to deter violations and prevent them from being seen as just a cost of doing business. The Motor Carrier Safety Act of 1993 aims to increase penalties for violations of federal motor carrier safety regulations. It proposes setting minimum penalty amounts to deter violations and improve compliance among motor carriers. The Act also aims to enhance information provided to motor carriers about driver safety performance and supporting documentation for duty status records. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF MINIMUM AMOUNT AND INCREASED MAXIMUM AMOUNTS. Amends Section 521(b)(2)(A) of title 49, United States Code to increase penalty amounts for violations. Minimum penalty raised to $500 and maximum to $1,000-$5,000. SEC. 4. DRIVER'S RECORD OF DUTY STATUS. The Secretary of Transportation must amend regulations to require retention of supporting documents related to a driver's duty status for at least 6 months, including driver and vehicle information. Supporting documents are defined as records used to verify entries in a driver's record. The motor carrier must verify entries in a driver's record of duty status, including trip reports, pay slips, bills of lading, and receipts for fuel, lodging, and tolls. SEC. 5. Safety performance history of new drivers. The Secretary of Transportation must amend regulations within 18 months to specify safety information required from motor carriers about drivers, request information from former employers within 30 days, and allow drivers to review and comment on the information. Safety information must include details of any motor vehicle accidents in the past 3 years. The Secretary of Transportation must amend regulations to specify safety information required from motor carriers about drivers, including any involvement in accidents in the past 3 years. Former employers must provide information on the driver's safety performance, including any violations related to alcohol or controlled substances in the preceding 3 years.
